intro: Chamaepeuce riphaea, commonly known as the Arctic bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Arctic and alpine regions of the northern hemisphere. It is a low-growing perennial herb that thrives in cold, rocky environments. The plant produces showy blue or violet flowers that bloom in late summer. Its leaves are typically small, hairy, and arranged in a rosette pattern to protect against harsh weather. Chamaepeuce riphaea plays an important role in its ecosystem by providing nectar for pollinators and stabilizing soil in its fragile habitat.
